newsitem.title: USA: Trustbuster - no anticompetitive aerospace mergers.
newsitem.headline: Trustbuster - no anticompetitive aerospace mergers.

text.p: Trustbuster Robert Pitofsky said Tuesday that despite reductions in military spending, the government should not permit aerospace mergers that are anticompetitive.

"The defense industry is undergoing a period of significant consolidation," the Federal Trade Commission chairman told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee. "This does not mean that policy makers should acquiesce in anticompetitive mergers."
Pitofsky said consolidation can occur in ways that protect the Department of Defense from becoming beholden to a single supplier, who would be free to control prices.
Pitofsky's testimony came as the Federal Trade Commission is considering the proposed merger of Boeing with McDonnell-Douglas.
Forty percent of Boeing's business and 75 percent of McDonnell-Douglas's business is with the military.
The merger also has implications for the commercial airline manufacturing industry. The only two American manufacturers of large commercial airliners are Boeing and Douglas.

Beyond focusing on whether mergers should occur, the Senate subcommittee looked into the practice of permitting companies to charge the Pengaton for a share of the costs of restructuring after they merge.
With the shrinking military budget, the Department of Defense has encouraged some mergers.

"We believe it makes good business sense to permit defense contractors to include in the price of defense goods those resaonable costs they incur to become more efficient producers," testified Eleanor Spector, Pentagon director of defense procurement.

But David Cooper, associate director of defense acquisition issues for the General Accounting Office, testified such efficiencies -- in other words, savings to taxpayers and the government -- have proved elusive.
"We have not seen the evidence of reduced prices," he said. Rep. Christopher Smith agreed.
"The so-called savings to the taxpayer are not verifiable," said Smith, a New Jersey Republican. In fact, he said, there would be greater net savings for taxpayers if the costs were not reimbursed.

"Why do these companies need taxpayer encouragement?" he asked. "If the underlying (merger) is prudent and profitable it will occur anyway." He called the payments an example of President Clinton's "corporate welfare."
Smith has introduced a measure to abolish such payments.
